title: Energy drink consumption: a rising public health issue
author: Amandeep Kaur; Hamza Yousuf; Devyani Ramgobin-Marshall; Rahul Jain; Rohit Jain
cleaned_text: TY - JOUR T1 - Energy drink consumption T2 - a rising public health issue AU - Kaur, Amandeep AU - Yousuf, Hamza AU N2 - Energy drink (ED) consumption has become a growing public health issue over the past few decades. Despite claims of being safe and beneficial, EDs have been linked to particularly fatal outcomes associated with the cardiovascular system which include atrial and ventricular arrhythmias, myocardial infarctions, cardiomyopathies, and sudden cardiac death. Large quantities of caffeine, taurine, sugars, and B-vitamins may be contributing to these outcomes by increasing the heart rate, blood pressure (BP), and contractility of the heart in addition to prolonging the QTc. There is still a substantial amount of unknown information on EDs that warrants more research and a dire need for age regulations, transparency of ingredients, clear labeling of adverse effects, and most importantly, education of consumers.
